We can use the product-to-sum identities for trigonometric functions. The sine and cosine product can be represented as 
\[
\sin(a) \cos(b) = \frac{1}{2} (\sin(a+b) + \sin(a-b)).
\]
For our integral, we have \(\sin(2x) \cos(3x)\), using \(a=2x\) and \(b=3x\), we get:
\[
\frac{1}{2}(\sin(5x) + \sin(-x)) = \frac{1}{2}(\sin(5x) - \sin(x)).
\]
Hence,
\[
\int \sin(2x) \cos(3x) \, dx = \frac{1}{2} \int (\sin(5x) - \sin(x)) \, dx.
\]
